text: Trübes dunkelrot mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Malzig, süßlich, fruchtig, überreife Bananen und Nelkenaromen, leicht alkoholisch, etwas Pfeffer.

22oz bottle pours out copper topped with a small head. Nose is sweet pit fruit rich malts some spice and little over ripe banana. Taste is more of the nice malts a little booze banana notes and spice present.

On tap a clear wine like orange, tiny ring of white head. Smells of clove, sweet malt and cherry, gum and juice. Taste is initial sweetness with cherry and fresh fruit there. Then it calms with a residual sourness and overripe fruit. Very layered and awesome

Bottle from Brewery Creek, VancouverHazy amber color with compact beige head. Good depth of malts, good body structure, the right sweetness, elegant all round, but also with a strange ester and soap aroma, candies, so I wonder which yeast was used here, and if the mild sourness comes from the spelt or because its not too fresh.But its a very positive experience.

Pours a deep amber, thin head, light beige. Rich caramel, plum sweet aroma, some raspberry in the aroma. Full mouthfeel, some barleywine qualities here, grapes, roasted toffee, caramel, but lots of deep sweetness to it, a tad boozy in the end.

Pours Amber with a thin beige head. Spicy sweet to the nose and the mouthfeel is similar. Tart and flavorful on the swallow with a pleasant lingering. The difference in the malt makes for a nice change of pace. Enjoyed it. Reminds me of a good whiskey, something to savor over a period of time.
Bottle - deep amber pour. Yeasty aroma, lots of spice. Sweet upfront with an astringent finish. Oily palate.

22 oz bottle poured at a tasting. Best by 6/17/15. Oops. Did this keep fermenting in the bottle? Tastes even stronger than the already sturdy abv offering, and its hardly close. Caramel amber color. Comes off as a barleywine. Tomato juice barleywine? Wheat finish. Need to try a fresh bottle of this. Ill actively seek one out if possible, and rerate. All things considered, pretty good.
Bomber to tulip. Rich malt and moderate spice. Hazy copper-brown with off white head. Flavor is banana and spice.
Bottle shared by a friend. Clear copper pour with a thin beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, booze and slight banana. Malty and caramelly flavor with lager yeast before a boozy and nutty finish.

Pours a beautiful caramel amber with a fizzy tan head of loose bubbles (aggressive pour). Would rate a five for appearance but, its flat looking. I know thats true to style but... Aroma is a bit simple but still very nice. Tons of malt, some floral hops, and alcohol. Taste is near perfect balance but theres some glue in there? Palate is nice as well but the slight stickiness adds to the sensation that youve been licking stamps. Of beers that I consider good; this is better than average. I wouldnt need to drink it or try it again.
Sampled at ABR 2015. Brown color, cloudy, just a little head. Lightly sweet aroma, some caramel. Some banana and wheat. Simple flavor, low carbonation, but what it has is good.
Bottle. Big sweet strawberry taste on the finish that ruined this one for me. Ok at first, but the sweet flavor built up very quickly.
Bottle. Dark ruby with little head. Very sweet with tons of dark fruit and a little clove. Rich and sticky. Alcohol is well integrated. Too sweet for me.

Bottle from my cellar. Pours Amber to medium brown with slight head that fades quickly. Aroma is cherries, unmalted barley, slight anise, stove top hard candy & mild astringent. Finish is mild sweet malt with a mild spelt presence.
Solid but not great. Really good aroma and a nice pungent taste. Tastes of malt and prune.
Looked like a really  good  beer, only Deschutes beer I wouldnt buy again.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Bottle at home. Pours a slightly hazy amber brown color with a small off white head that settled into a thin film. The aroma and flavor have big banana character, caramel, some dark fruits, slightly nutty, clove, bubble gum, interesting that this seems light with the 10.7% alcohol, this is on the sweet side and Im glad the wife helped me finish it off.

650ml bottle pours black in color with a finger of off-white head that leaves very little lacing on the glass. Aroma is dark fruits, citrus and banana with some hints of chocolate and grass. Taste is a citrus and grassy hop bitterness with a dark fruit, banana and light chocolate malty sweetness. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, this is an impressive brew for the style and although it is darker than I expected, it may even be better because of this. Recommended.
Brick red with a tan head. Malt driven profile with dough and toasted bread. Full dark fruit, sweet booze, and a hint of spice. Medium body. Finishes with nice booze, sweet malt, spice. Enjoyable.
Dark pour, fair sized head. Malt forwward, spicy, dark bread. Fairly spicy, getting more clove than any of the other mentioned flavours. Bready, a touch on the sweet side. Medium to heavier body.
Americos bottle. Mollases and malt and a littlevomit aroma.Grows on me. Smooth with some sharp spelt.
Bomber, 6/6/15. Hazy amber, no head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, raisin. The taste is toffee, caramel, smoke, toasted malt, anise, raisin. Medium bodied, low carbonation, chewy, dark.
(22oz bottle) Pours a brown body with a moderate beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, citrus, clove, bubblegum, and banana. Flavor of wheat, banana,, caramel, clove, and some chocolate.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, best before 6/17/2015. Pours slightly hazy deep ruby red/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big raisin, plum, apple, lemon, orange, banana, clove, bubblegum, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toast, light herbal, light nuttiness, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and fruity/spicy yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of big raisin, plum, apple, lemon, orange, banana, clove, bubblegum, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toast, light herbal, light nuttiness, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of earthy yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, apple, lemon, orange, banana, clove, bubblegum, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toast, light nuttiness, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt and fruity/spicy yeast flavors; with an awesome malt/yeast balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth and fairly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming lingering after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice weizen bock style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and fruity/spicy yeast flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Spicy sweet clove aroma with banana, vanilla, caramel, bread, toast, and nuts.
Pours a clear brownish amber with small creamy yellowish head.
Bready banana flavor with sweet alcohol, raisin, caramel, underlying spice. Very rich malty flavor.
Full creamy body, medium co2, alcohol warmth, lingering sticky spiciness.
A decent sipping beer. I think alcohol is a bit high on this one. Probabaly make an excellent 8% beer. It's a bit much and takes away from drinkability.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Lost review from last fall. Pours hazy orange-amber with a thin off-white head. Banana, caramel, citrus and spice in delicious balance.

Bottle. Poured an clear brown color with an average creamy off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy citrus, banana and clove and alcohol aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

Bottle: Dark copper color with a thin ring of beige head. Nose has a little bit of spice, but mostly malty and fruity sweetness. Banana comes out in the taste, albeit lightly, with more malty and fruity sweetness. More of a pitted fruit taste cant nail it down to one thing. Finishes creamy and I like way the modest level of cloves works with the fruit and malty sweetness. Decent.

On tap at Republic. Pours a hazy amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a decent amount of clove with sweet grains and a hint of light spice. Flavor has sweet grain and clove with some bread and light booze.
Reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma is banana, cloves and sweetness. Taste is creamy, soft, banana, clove, faint spiciness in the finish. Goes down easy and smooth.
Poured from a bottle it is a cloudy amber color with a slight head. The aroma is banana the taste is strong sweet citrus flavor and some bubblegum
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours hazy copper with an ecru head. Caramel nose. Flavors of raisin and cloves. Smooth, mellow finish.

Pours pale ruby mahogany with a small light beige head. Smells sweet, banana, bubblegum, clove. Taste is sweet, bubblegum, hints of banana. Full-bodied with a smooth texture, and soft mouth-carbonation, Deschutes Doppel Dinkle Bock finishes with a soft, sweet fruitiness.

From t;he North Coast Coop in Eureka, CA. This brew pours a cloudy and somewhat muddy amber with an off-white head.. Light lacing rings. Nose of banana. Full body. Very creamy and smooth in the mouth. The flavor is brown sugar, banana, cloves, and rich malts. Finishes on the sweet side but the spiciness and banana hangs on. Really rich and tasty.

Deep amber pour, no head to speak of. Nose is a touch of yeast, toffee , and alcohol. Mostly sweet. Middle is like liquid caramel with hints of currants and cherries. Finish is sweet with a flourish of banana on the way out. Complex, but a l;little boozy for me.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange red color. Aroma is big caramel clay sweetness. Light nutty notes. Flavor is floral, tart, citrus and caramel sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle:
Cloudy brown with a small tan head.
Aroma of dark fruit and brownies.
Taste is dark banana, nuts, caramel malt.
Sweet, dark bread, malty...
Very rich....huge amounts of sweet flavour.
Pours a reddish brown color with a small off white bubbly head. Notes of bubble gum, cereal grains, dried figs, and clove. Very sweet
Bottle (22oz): Cloudy brown with minimal head. light carbonation. Medium body. Aroma mostly yeasty funk. Taste was somewhat sweet. very malty.

Bomber poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromasof caramel, banana, yeast, wheat, bubblegum and light clove. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel, wheat, light banana and light clove with a smoth lingering caramel finish.
Bottle. Pretty good stuff. Solid beer fo sho. Interesting with fruity notes. Very odd.
Im not a big fan of the style, but this a pretty great doppelbock. Malty and rich, deep brownish amber, belgiany aromas a spicy sweet finish.

[Tap] Light brown clear pour with about an inch of head on top. Malty aroma includes hints of alcohol as well. Caramel, grains, sweet toffee, booze, residual sugars and clove throughout the taste. The yeasty flavors dont come out much in the background of this malt bomb. I doubt I would order this again.

Nothing compelling here. Honey pour with a small eggshell pour. Slight banana, clove, black pepper, orange zest, and lemongrass. Sweet malt balances out the more aggressive flavors. Trouble is, I CRAVE aggressive. High ABV but not as bold as I would like.

Pours a cloudy amber, with whitish tan head. Aroma of a Belgian; malty with dark fruits. Taste is rich and malty, somewhere between a Doppelbock and a Belgian; lots of character and very drinkable. Thumbs up.

Nicely crafted weizen bock, one of my favorite German styles. Pours dark amber with a small fluffy beige head, lots of sticky lacing. Nice weizen aromas up front, slightly sweet, bananas, bubblegum, etc. Taste brings plenty of spelt/dinkel sweetness, and plenty of warmth on the finish. Nice collaboration and use of the dinkel grain.
22 oz bottle. Aroma: malty, boozy, and skunky, with hints of biscuit, maple, and grape juice. Taste/Palate: starts sweet and crisp, and finishes tart and creamy.
Poured from a 22. Flavor is sweet with banana and clove. Has a decent enough malt backbone to provide some depth. There is a strange plastic after taste to it.

Pours hazy deep chestnut brown with a medium beige head, moderate retention, very fine lacing. Aromas of tart cherry, caramel, banana, toast, grass, spice. Medium body, creamy. Medium sweet, light citrus, light bitter finish. A little on the sweet and boozy side.

Bottle. Grainy orange, clove, caramel malt aroma. Hazy orange-brown with minimal head. Sweet creamy banana/orange clove, caramel malt and lightly bitter herbal and alcohol flavor. Love the taste that the Dinkel imparts - kind of shocked to see Deschutes collaborate with Distelhaeuser (one of my locals when I lived near Wuerzburg). Would loved to see more Dinkelbiers in the states.
On tap at Cuginos. It poured a hazy brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was of malts, bread with hints of ester and alcohol. The taste was of bread, esters and big alcohol flavors. Nice.

Nice. Aroma of wheat even though I know there wasnt any used and clove. Soft brown color with a light head. Full of flavor with caramelized sugar and burnt wheat and biscuit. Full, smooth palate with average carbination. Bold beer.
Cloudy amber brown with generous tan head. Aroma of whole grain, bananas, caramel, raisins, markers. Tastes like burnt caramel - creme brulee. Palate is clean, some boozy heat.

Bottle... Pours clear and brown with no head. The aromatic highlights are sassafras and other herbs and roots  some notes of root beer or sarsaparilla. Full-bodied and sticky with modest carbonation. The flavor is sweet and caramely with an odd - but welcomed - banana component in both the flavor and finish. Bottle courtesy of growler!
Draft. Lighter full body. Fair amount of alcohol. wheat balanced with maltiness. Fair sweetness. Better than many of its peers, but not near the best.
Bomber. Pours clear brown, tiny head and minimal lace. Aroma is brown sugar and nutmeg. Very sweet and fruity, bubblegum and clove. Finishes long and sweet.

Bottle to snifter. Nose is like candy sugar with some light esters, like Belgian ale almost. Pour is a hazy red, with a minimal off white head that dies quickly. Taste is very sweet initially followed by a light bitterness. Full of fruitiness and a slight vanilla note. Didnt realize this was a weizen bock. Guess I should read better. Malt seems a bit one dimensional and gives way to a peppery alcohol finish after a couple sips. Im mostly disappointed.

Refrigerated brown bomber, best by June 2015, poured into a weizen glass. clear copper with small beige head. Aroma is bready, medium body, rough texturer, medium/low carbonation, and little small-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel, bread, sweet banana, and some alcohol. Alcohol is quite a bit of the taste.

22 oz bottle, poured into a tulip glass as room temperature.

A: Pours a deep orange-copper, with some mild cloudiness, and forms a three-finger pale orange head that collapses rather quickly into a cap and ring.

S: Caramel and toffee malt notes dominate the opening of the aroma, and are quickly joined by what seems like pine sap. Some fruit notes also appear, like overripe pear and raisin, and perhaps a vaguely banana-bready tinge.

T: Thats an interesting approach to a weizenbock. The piney scent from the aroma carries forward into the beer, giving the whole flavor profile a wallop that is tough for me to get past, and highlighting the alcohol heat thats along. However, beneath that, theres a parade of fruit esters - cherries, overripe pear, raisins, and tart apple. Further beneath that lurks the shades of banana bread with toffee replacing the nuts, alongside clove and coriander spices. The finish is pure alcohol burn, perhaps with some of that pine-ness along.

M: Creamy, full, and sticky, with high carbonation that carries a sharp tang with it, and plenty of alcohol heat - this does not hide its ABV at all.

O: Im torn here. While the flavor profile offers significant complexity, it also heavily features a two-note barrage of pine and alcohol, to me. While the mouthfeel is exactly what one wants out of a weizenbock in consistency, the carbonation and heat are a bit excessive. I imagine for those who are less hop-sensitive than I am, this is an outright good beer. I am left wondering if I would repeat it given the opportunity.

On the side, the best by date says "06/17/15."
This was poured into a weizen glass.
The appearance was a hazy dark brown color with a one finger white to off white foamy head that settled within about a minute. Light lacing conclaved around the sides of the glass.
The smell started off with a caramelized / bready spice. As it warmed, it seemed that the spice leaned towards the clove side.
The taste had a sticky sweet bready caramel connotation sliding across my tongue. Super sticky sweet caramel aftertaste.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a good sipping quality about it. Sweet bready caramel malt moves finely across my tongue.
Overall, as a weizenbock, I didnt get as much of the wheatiness as I expected. For me, I still liked it and still would bang it again.
Bottle from Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours reddish brown with a pretty beige head and a treacle aroma. There is a full-bodied caramel malt flavor with a dry bitter finish.

Bottle, muddy brown pour with a finger of light white head. Aroma, spices, sweet malts, and dark fruit. Taste is malty sweetness, followed by spices, brown sugar and more clove like spice, aftertaste is sweet, carbonation and mouthfeel are medium. Really tasty!
GABF 2014. Pours a somewhat cloudy brown appearance with a light brown head. Theres some caramel, chocolate, banana, and gooey caramel. Quite a bit of banana, actually. Overall, ok.

On tap at Whole Foods Roseville... Caramel colored... Aroma of caramel, wheat akin to a dunkel weizen... Notes of ripe bananas... Flavor is sweet, overripe fruits, bananas, raisins... Yeasty, wheaty finish... Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bomber to glass - just noticed that damn near every weizen bock I drink I like.. this is the same - I get dark fruits and sugar in aroma (not banana). Taste is same with soft carbonation; alcohol is hidden; my one nitpick is that it is cloyingly sweet after 10-12 oz... better shared. still good stuff!

Bomber shared with hakes at the DUB, aroma like a sour, color is deep brown, (I think its dark in here), taste is raisen fruit, alcohol, for a weizen bock, (which I never buy pourposly), this shits awesome,

Aromas of bubblegum and clove mixed with caramel and bready malts. Flavour has less banana and clove and more toffee and caramel sweetness, lightly spicey. Way too sweet, on the verge of cloying for me.

A malty sweet nose - carmel with hints of banana and spice rise from a slightly hazy dark copperish hued pour with no head or lacing. The taste is sweet - sweet malt (spelt), banana, caramel, cloves, and hints of spice. There is a long lingering malty aftertaste. Medium body and medium carbonation. Overall, while somewhat sweet, this beer should complement a number of different foods.
Bomber courtesy of Lynn on wedding weekend (thanks!). Copper pour, light tan-white head. Aroma of bubblegum, caramel, candy, sugar. Tastes are pepper, syrup, wheat, clove, grass. Not my thing.
Cloudy orange-ish pour with a short tan head. Sweet malty nose, citrus , caramel with a spicy finish

Poured from a 22oz bottle -- Cloudy copper poor with no head. Smells of alcohol, spice and malt. Flavor is identical to the smell, spicy caramel that smooths out into a thin mellow finish. The only thing that would make this better is a little more body.

Pours a clear copper with an off white head and good lacing. Aroma of clove, banana and spices. Taste is similar with banana and clove, with some yeasty character and mild spices. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Typical Weizenbock with a bit more spice flavor.

Loads of banana, juicy fruit, clove and spiciness in the aroma and taste. Moderately sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Slightly murky reddish brown, minimal cream head. Smells of juicy fruit, apple, pear. Taste is fruity caramel sweetness, pear, apple, ends with more caramel sweetness, breadiness, and some of the juicy fruit in there as well. The juicy fruit like flavors don't mesh too well as it is somewhat overwhelming. Ok flavors overall, average. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours carmel orange with a tiny head and not much lacing. big bold nose of sugar and malt and yeast. attack is heavy, think malty sweetness. finishes is slow and surprisingly dry for a beer that attacks sweet.
October 16, 2014 - tap at Valley Tap. Brownish orange pour with limited head. Aroma was sweet, grain and fruit. Taste was consistent with aroma, but also had some spice.
Great aroma, bubblegum and banana. A very nice beer! My first of this variety, but aroma it is second to none. Cheers!

22 oz bottle- Pours a nice hazy autumn orange with a one finger off white head that reduces to a blanket. Aroma is Bavarian yeast, banana and clove, sweet, like banana runts. Taste is banana and clove, Bavarian yeast again, not as sweet as the aroma, alcohol is noticeable but in check given the high abv. Better than i was expecting, for some reason I was putting this one off.

Tap pours a dark auburn with khaki fizz. The aroma is nice and malty with a light fruity sweetness. It Is a delicious big German beer but still holds all the good values of the style. A little earthy and drying on the backend with loads of grain, caramel malts and light grainy spices. Nothing explosive but very nice.

I love weizen bocks and this is a fabulous one. The aroma blew me away with sweet bubblegum, candy and banana. Like a really intense hefeweizen. Taste is also very sweet without being too sweet although there were moments I thought it was overdoing it. But those were brief. Overall pretty awesome.
Whoa. This is quite a beer. Really big. Aromas of wheat and spice. More spice on the tongue along with sweet grains and booze. Really good...but a sipper.

Dark amber to chestnut pour with a 2 finger creamy beige head. Aroma is banana, bubblegum, toast, hints of dark fruit, sweet and toasty wheat and tangy citrus. Flavor is big sweet yeasty wheat bread up front, then some graham cracker, boozy dark fruit, banana, a little toffee, light almond sweetness, some pie spice and citrus and floral hops to the finish.. Medium to heavy body, chewy feel , light carbonation and a still chewy, but slightly drier finish.Good stuff overall, tons of wheat malt character.

22 ounce bottle, label says best before 06/17/15. Served in a mug, the beer pours a burnt orange color with about a half inch light tan creamy head. The head stays around a while, and theres a decent amount of lacing. Aroma is nice, the brew smells like cloves, banana, bubblegum, caramel, and some candied oranges. I think the taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also bready malt and a sweet spiciness noticeable too. Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its creamy and coating with moderate carbonation. Its also smooth and easy to drink, the 10.7% ABV is well hidden. I liked this brew, definitely worth a try! I know I wouldnt mind getting another bottle of this.

Lots of fruity sweetness and caramel. Floral and pineapple sweetness. Cloudy copper with a decent beige head. Really sweet stone fruit, caramel and that pineapple hits hard again. Not sure I can understand the style
Dirty caramel with a red tint. Smells like sour sweet dense wheat malt. Aroma of fresh banana. One of the most complex best tasting dunkels and its made in the USA... imagine that.
Draft at Imbibe Wine. Nose is banana, bodacious bubblegum, cloves, candisugar. Clear light amber with a medium beige head. Flavor is sweet ripe bananas with nice Belgian spiciness and fruitiness.
On tap at Alla Spina. Poured a deeper copper, almost brown color with a thin sized off white head. Dark fruits, some spice, bananas, and citrus. Overall alcohol content well hidden.
Attractive amber, good head. Sweet front, frothy and rich. Grape notes beneath obvious banana. My favorite beer of the festival. (At Ale Jail Anniversary Party 2014)
Bottled, dark brown to reddish, light tan foam, chocolate banana and spice flavors, creamy banana aroma, light finish

Bottle: Poured a dark brown with reddish orange edges, head was tan carbonated bubbles. Aroma is mixed with fruits mainly banana, bubblegum malt, light clove, and very appealing. The taste on the other hand is confused, very yeasty and just when you start to get hints of other flavors the clove overpowers to a tingly finish.
Dark red. Small whitish head. Cloves and banana and enough bread to remind you of a good Belgian double. Very well done, as expected by Deschutes.

Draft at Ciceros. Some red in the color and it is hazy and cool looking. Just all kinds of sweet fruit here. Some alcohol and an interesting base. A little bit hot but now that I see the ABV it is now wonder. Good stuff.

650ml bottle. Hazy brown pour with a small off-white head that has fair retention. The aroma is fruity with caramel apples, bananas, pears and peaches. The taste, like the aroma, is very forward with the fruits: I get more caramel apples, bananas and pears. The palate is full and smooth and the carbonation is lively. Finishes long and sweet. Overall: Very tasty stuff, definitely a bit off the beaten path beer wise.
Spicy phenols, caramelized banana, crusty bread, dried fruit, baked apple. Moderately warming. Really nice

650ml bottle. Red pour, quickly dissipating head. Smell is banana and clove, dark fruits, dark malt, woah this is a weizenbock, not a doppelbock. Flavor is sweet and sherry-like, heavy booze, dark fruits banana. Noticeable spelt character. Just too sweet, boozy and large.  This is abrasively boozy, anybody who doesnt think so must be drowning in black tuesday and side pocket malt liquor. Would think a German brewery being involved would mak eit a bit more restrained and pleasant but this is probably their biggest most extreme brew to date. Why is this getting rated so high? Has anyone had Aventinus, that just blows this thing completely out of the water.

Aroma: Touch sour cherry, green banana, roasty grain and caramel, 
Flavor: Roasty caramel, sour cherry, bubble gum (mid-palate only), banana, sweet malt, and more sour cherry on a long finish as well as a bready character.

Bomber from Wegmans. Pours turbid ruby with minimal off-white head. Nose is caramel malt, vinous fruit, hops, banana,mild butyric acid. Tastes dense and caramelly, with some hops, earthy molasses notes, hops,banana, and some vinyls. This one is a bit rough around the edges. Ah, hell, this one is rougher around the edges than a sharks skin petted in the wrong direction.
Draft. Mahogany beer with a cream head. Malt and dark fruit aroma with light spice. Dark fruit and caramel flavor with rich malt. Medium bodied. Dark fruit and caramel lingers with rich malt.

22 oz. bottle, pours a hazy burgundy with a tiny head. Aroma brings out dark fruits and rich toffee. Flavour is along the same lines, with toffee and rich dark fruits, with a complex profile. Very elegant and deep, with a finish of light alcohol. Excellent stuff.
At Kaiser Tiger. Malty with dried fruit flavors. A lot of banana and clove like a hefeweizen which was OK but sometimes out of place. Otherwise good. Serving: tap

Had this on draft at a local event where Deschutes and Seventh Son celebrated homebrewing. The beer pours a beautiful mahogany with thin off-white head that lasts only a minute or two. The aroma is a mix of cloves, banana, malt, sweetness, and subtle spice. The flavor is much the same. Its sweet, intensely malty, with some fruit and spice thrown in. Almost like a cross between a Belgian beer and a Hefeweizen. Absolutely delicious and my favorite Deschutes beer by far. I hope they make it a part of their regular line-up someday.
22 oz bottle. Brown with a decent beige head. Aroma is of clove, heavy malt, prunes, light banana and toffee. Taste is of malt, booze, caramel, toffee, banana, clove and cinnamon.
Bottle. The look is a cashew colored head, brown colored, and ok. The smell is yeasty, banana, fruit, crust, malt deep, and ok. The taste is sweet, fruit, yeast, ok, and interesting.

Draught. Pours a hazy reddish amber with a small tan head on there. Nose has some wheat and fruit to it, and is only OK to me. Taste is sweet with some candy elements to it and a bit of caramel. Pretty smooth, though.

Bottle, shared by TvM at game night. Very hazy orange amber, leaning more toward amber. Sweet caramel, dark fruits, soft banana. Quite estery, more weizenbockish than doppelbockish, but Im not complaining! Very good.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 650 ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with very little head. Aromas of raisins, figs, copper, and nuts. Flavors of raisins, figs, sweet malts, cloves, banana chips and other Christmas-y spices. A lot going on. ABV pretty much hidden though a warm finish. Very nice.

The beer pours a hazy chestnut color with a small white ring instead of a head. The aroma is a nice blend of toasted and caramel malts, fig, banana, and a hint of booze; the flavor is mildly sweet, slightly umami, and slightly sour with tons of malt character coming through. The palate complements the taste well due to the medium-full body, oily texture, soft carbonation, and malty sweet finish.

Draft at Kaiser Tiger. Pours a deep, clear amber with a small off-white head that settles into a ring. Gigantic banana note throughout this, along with caramel, clove, bubblegum, mellow spices (allspice, nutmeg, faint pepper), wheat, and syrup. Full-bodied, with a chrewy, coating mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Drinks like a gigantic weizenbock. A bit cloying; I could only handle a few ounces. Glad we had a small one.

Bomber. Aroma consists of caramel, dark fruit, toast, bubblegum. Pours hazy brown with orange tints; has a medium beige head that falls after a minute. Taste is sweet and malty, toasty and caramelly, lightly tart; flavors of licorice, Bavarian yeast compounds, hot alcohol (not quite over the top). Mouthfeel is oily, carbonation fine, full body. Not bad.

22oz bottle, shared with Taylor B. Best by 6/17/15. ABV labeled 10.7%. Kind of a half hazy toasty red brown color. Thin off-white head. Some loose dots of lace. Bigger body. Good full smooth kind of creamy lighter carbonation. Kind of slick. Surprising amount of fermented darker banana aroma. Drinks like a weizenbock. I like that. Some darker nutty dark fruity malts. Doesnt drink as heavy as a doppelbock, or even a 10.7% weizen bock usually does. Moderate sweet taste. Light bitter. Lightly spicy. Alcohol is impressively well hidden. Pretty awesome weizenbock. Tastes like a weizenbock.
22 ounce bottle from Whole Foods. Caramel and banana gum. Some malt and sweetness. Doesnt taste like such a big ABV beer.

I get a bavarian yeast and bubblegum in this hazy reddish brown brew with an offwhite. The taste is very malty sweet and a bit spicy wit a good carb and the feel of alcohol. Has an earthy taste with a very sweet aftertaste. Very decent doppelbock.
Cloudy amber-brown, sweet, bubblegum, creamy body, and a dash of alcohol in the finish. Seems reasonably well-made but its over 30 degrees, this is so not the beer I want right now.

BEER #5500! dark mahaogony pour, decent head. Big bready boozy dark fruit aroma. Toasted grains and plum. Some bubble gum in the flavor throws me off a bit, but its enjoyable. More dough and fruit. A little too much alcohol as it warms prevents this really good beer from being an epically awesome beer. At 8% this would be WAY up there as the heat is the only fault. Sweetish finish."

This is like a mixture of pie and an amped up hefeweizen. It pours an almost reddish color and the nose has a bit of sawdust to it. Very pleasant woody-ness with a bit of pepper. But then you get a hit of clove mixed with bubblegum and a small dose of banana. But it has a bigger malt profile and sticks around. Very hearty this drink is.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, dark reddish brown pour with white head, aroma brought notes of dark fruit, caramel, toffee, caramelized sugars, nutty notes into some nice banana, clove notes, hints of spice in there as well. Taste is a mix of grass, toffee, spice, caramel into some banana, clove, some red and dark fruit notes into some more yeasty spice, finishing sweet.

Large bottle purchased at Elevated in South Mpls. Consumed in Duvel tulip glass which isnt ideal but serves as a decent serving vessel. The aroma is a big star here...lots of deep, sweetness and dark fruits. Rare to get bubblegum as a flavor but Deschutes hits the mark. Taste that follows is smooth and actually hides the alcohol relatively well. Lots of spice (probably cloves) comes into play and finish is reminiscent of standard doppel bocks. It lingers longer than expected but never leaves the "I enjoyed this beer" zone. I give Deschutes credit for venturing outside their typical comfort zone and taking a run at this style. Definitely worth another try.

Bomber. Pours a deep honey-amber color, pillowy off-white head with exceptional retention and lacing to match. Nose is clove, banana, stone fruit, Bazooka Joe, toffee. Mouth is rich and almost custard-like, sweet caramelly malts, candy-sugar, honey, more of that clove and banana, finishes with bubblegum and a trace of boozy-ness. Really nice doppel. Prost!

Bomber. Belgian malt aroma with notes of banana, clove, and citrus with a bit of spice. Pours deep caramel colored with a thin white head and good lacing. Rich, sweet Belgian malt with good banana and citrus flavors that play well together. Finishes smooth with the sweet malt flavors throughout with clove and other spices coming through as well. Good stuff.
Aroma of banana/bubblegum/clove. Amber color, moderately cloudy, thin foamy white head, no lacing. Taste of banana/bubblegum/cloves, slightly spicy.

Smells really nice, of bananas and cloves, like a German hefe really. The flavor is super super sweet, with a saguaro flavor tHat really dominates everything else. Eventually able to drink it all, but a one timer for sure.
Aroma is caramel, earthiness, tangy fruit and a hint of spice. The flavor is caramel, bananas/bubblegum, fruit, mild sweetness and a long and tart finish, with the alcohol sneaking in late.

Draft at SB. Pours a murky dark amber with a dense and creamy tan head that goes away. Fully agree on the commercial description for aromatics, actually--getting bubblegum, banana, clove, citrus, and a little spice in the back. Sums it up. Sticky thick body with soft carb. Overly sweet; cloying mid palate. Lots of estery sweetness and lots of odd malty tang as well. Cloying finish. Even a 4-oz pour was a bit much, but they succeeded in hitting the scope of what they were doing here. Its just that what they were doing was a fair ways off the beaten path.

Bottle - Lots of fruity sweetness and caramel. Floral and pineapple sweetness. Cloudy copper with a decent beige head. Really sweet stone fruit, caramel and that pineapple hits hard again. Not sure I can understand the style.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is cloudy dark amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel), with notes of banana, clove, toffee, apple, raisin, alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy/velvety texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Sure seems like Weizenbock to me, has a big banana-clove Weissbier nose, which straight doppelbocks dont really have. Regardless, it smells nice. Fairly sweet in the mouth, and a little sticky-syrupy, but its not thick and goopy, so its still reasonably drinkable. Pretty good if not great.

On draught at Deschutes Brewery & Public House. Maple syrup in color. Aroma is cinnamon, banana bread, caramel apple, and clove. Taste is similar to aroma, but the bananas become bananas foster and there is a slight amount of balancing bitterness. Flavorful and not to heavy for such a big beer.
Bomber. Pours reddish brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, fruit, and spice. Taste is sweet malt, caramel, banana, and spices. Too much malt for me.

All the rate flavor notes are there for a superb doppelbock, although may be a bit too syrupy. The only big negative here is the ABV is just too high. Theres a lot of alcohol heat going on, which is unnecessary. At 8-9%, this wouldve been top of the crowd.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours hazy reddish toffee color, with thin creamy off-white head. Aroma is rather thin sweet boozy bready caramel malt, some light roastiness. Taste is rich thick chewy roasty malt, huge layers of sweetness from both the malt and candi sugar. Some Belgian spice and clove notes, but theyre relatively restrained. Clearly not a traditional doppelbock but easily one of the best Ive had... tons of rich malt with almost no harshness. Cant say Ive had a spelt beer before, but that must be working here.

It pours a semi clear deep brown/red. A good head of foam to start off with but that shrinks quickly and leaves no foam, no lacing.

Big notes of cloves, grain, sweet malt, in that order.

Big clove and big grain in the taste. Some not so subtle flavours of bubblegum. The alcohol, I can feel and I can taste.

Medium body, lightish carbonation, 

I reckon this is a decent stab at a Doppelbock but it didnt quite reach its destination.

651 ml. bottle. BBD 6/17/15. Pours a medium, tiny bubbled, well retained, ivory head, over a hazy, dark amber (SRM 15) body......nose is sweet, with banana/bubblegum, brown sugar notes, minimal hop tones, balance heavily to the malts.....taste is very sweet, with heavy banana/bubblegum, dried fruits including plum, raisin, also light clove, brown sugar, molasses, minimal hop bitterness or other notes, balance heavily to the malts....mouth feel, medium heavy body, sticky, alcohol heat present, slight tingle, with creaminess from carbonation. This is a Fruit Flys dream beer. The heavy sweetness, with the primary aroma and flavor of banana dominating all the other aromas and flavors in this very complex beer, will make it easy to either love or hate. Dopplebocks do not use wheat but are made primarily with Munich or Vienna malts. This beer is found in the craft beer never-never land between a Weizenbock and a Dopplebock. This probably should have been entered, by the brewery as a  Weizenbock. It is in other words an experiment. It does not taste bad as long as you like sweet beers, and are not concerned in any way about style. BJCP 5/3/10/4/5

Bomber from Capitol Beer in Sacramento, CA. Pours very hazy amber/copper with a very slight head. Aroma of banana ester, something like spicy malt, and an earthy note. Full bodied without doubt. Flavor is lots of banana ester, brown sugar, something like clove, and something else, I think. Not sure. This is rather strongly flavored, and far from dry. Good stuff tho. Mouth smacking.

On Tap at BitterCreek Ale House on Deschutes "not" tap Take Over. Hazy redish amber with a full fluffy off-white head. Sweet malty aroma. I dont get much of the bubble gum notes, but carmelized dark pitted fruit comes through.. Similar to the Stoic(s) I had earlier. More flat bitter flavor though and some of that gum and spiciness comes through in the after taste. Different than my ideal DB but a rich malty example witha dry and fairly sharp trailer.

Wow, this beer is amazing! Like amazing banana bread in a glass. Smooth clove, and a little spicy. No hint of the alcohol at 10.5%! This is what a doppelbock should taste like! Nice full body as well!

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2015 Happy to add and be the first to rate this brand new Deschutes collab with Distelhauser. Great aroma of booze, sweet butter scotch malt, banana, clove, bubble gum, and roast. Small head retains well; appearance between copper and brown. Taste is lots of bubble gum up front with clove, banana, pils and wheat bread malt. Alcohol is amazingly well-hidden. Super tasty brew with a classy, luxurious palate. Wow, this is great stuff.  A must for malt-heads.  UPDATE: I see I originally miscategorized this.  The "doppel" threw me off into thinking it was a doppelbock.  Weizenbock is the best-fit category.
